item.title: Syllabus (Fall 2018)
item.description: Stat 110: Fundamentals of statistics Required software JMP - available from WSU network for free. Download instructions Optional text There is no text required for this course. However, if you would like to refer to a textbook, a good reference is Unlocking the Power of Data by Lock, Lock, Lock, Lock, and Lock. Prerequisites Qualifying score on the mathematics placement exam or MATH 050. Basic Skills Learning Outcomes

item.title: Stat 110: Fundamentals of statistics (Fall 2018)
item.description: Office hours (Gildemeister 124D) MWF: 9:30-11:30; Tue/Th 8:30-10:30 Upcoming Date Done by class In class Tues 11/27 Lecture 16 videos; practice quiz Practice problem, D2L quiz Thurs 11/29 HW 9 (random groups) Extra credit opportunities 0.5% overall each added on to final grade: Attend any/all of the Identity and Empathy workshops; upload responses to the following questions to D2L.

item.title: Stat 303: Intro to engineering statistics (Fall 2018)
item.description: Fall 2018 Office hours MWF 9:30-11:30; Tues/Th 8:30-10:30 Syllabus Resources Free Intro to R course on Data Camp Writing R functions tutorial Base R R Studio Open source probability and statistics textbook Lectures Lecture 1: Intro to probability Lecture 2: Counting methods Lecture 3: Conditional probability and independence Lecture 4: discrete random variables Lecture 5: parametric discrete distributions Lecture 6: hypothesis testing with discrete data Lecture 7: decision errors and power Lecture 8: continuous random variables Lecture 9: parametric continuous distributions Lecture 10: sampling distributions Lecture 11: confidence intervals for a population mean Lecture 12: hypothesis tests for a population mean | Video lecture Lecture 13: testing differences in means with independent samples Homework Homework 1 (getting up and running with R and R Markdown) | KEY Homework 2 (Due 9/20) | KEY Homework 3 (Due 9/30) | KEY Homework 4 (Due 10/9) | KEY Homework 5 | KEY

item.title: Stat 370: Statistical consulting and communication
item.description: Resources Syllabus Dropbox folder (password sent via email) Ideal report guidelines Sample report 1 Sample report 2 Sample report 3 Written report rubric Presentation rubric: Visual Aids Presentation rubric: oral Peer evaluation survey Lectures What is a statistical consultant? item.title: Syllabus
item.description: STAT 450: Mathematical statistics I Fall 2018 INSTRUCTOR: Dr. Silas Bergen OFFICE: Gildemeister 124D Prerequisites: Math 312 (Multivariable calculus) Math 337 (Probability); concurrent enrollment OK Eng 111 Course summary STAT 450 and 460 are courses in mathematical statistics intended for upper-level undergraduate students in the mathematical sciences. The goal in STAT 450 is provide a solid foundation in the theory of random variables, probability distributions, and convergence in probability and distribution.

Download instructions for WSU laptops Optional text There is no text required for this course. However, if you would like to refer to a textbook, a good reference is Unlocking the Power of Data by Lock, Lock, Lock, Lock, and Lock. item.title: Stat 310: Intermediate statistics (Spring 2018)

Link to promo Resources Syllabus JMP installation instructions JMP script for calculating binomial probabilities Notes Handout 1: Review of statistical concepts Handout 2: Decision errors and statistical power Handout 3: Introduction to modeling Handout 4: Introduction to simple linear regression Handout 5: Introduction to simple linear regression (part 2) Handout 6: Introduction to multiple linear regression Handout 7: Interactions Handout 8: cross validation and model violation Handout 9: One-way ANOVA Handout 10: Factorial ANOVA Handout 11: ANCOVA Handout 12: Intro to logistic regression Handout 13: Assessing predictive ability of logistic regression models Activities Vitruvian man activity Interaction activity ANOVA activity Pairwise comparisons activity Factorial ANOVA activity ANCOVA activity Logistic regression activity Homework Homework 1 (Due 1/25) | KEY Homework 2 (Due 2/1) | KEY Homework 3 (Due 2/8) | KEY Homework 4 (Due 2/15) | KEY Homework 5 (Due 2/22) | KEY Homework 6 (Due 3/22) | KEY Homework 7 (Due 4/26) | KEY Writing Assignment Prompt Data CrowdGrader link Exams Practice Exam 1 2nd Practice Exam 1 Exam 1 (Take home portion) | Trump vote data | WAPS data | Cedar data Practice Exam 2 | KEY Practice final | KEY Take home final exam | Sitting data for Q1 | Species data for Q2 | Breast cancer cell data for Q3 Data Birth weight data | JMP Breast cancer cell data | JMP Calorie data | JMP | CSV Car data | JMP DIEP data | JMP | CSV FEV data | JMP Fruit fly data | JMP Hawk data | JMP Haystack data | JMP Levee data | JMP Med GPA data | JMP MLB standings data | JMP New York Times/Globe data | JMP Pig data | JMP PIMA diabetes data | JMP Poison data | JMP Real estate data | JMP Silly little data | JMP Student Survey Data | JMP Trombone data | JMP Vitruvian man data | JMP World bank data | JMP

item.title: Syllabus
item.description: STAT 310: Intermediate Statistics Textbook There is no required text for this class. A recommended text for student reference is Stat 2: Building Models for a World of Data by Cannon et al. This text is well-written and has some nice problems for additional student practice. However, it can get technical at times. You will not need this text to complete the homework or succeed on exams. Prerequisites Stat 110, STAT 210, STAT 303, STAT 305, PSY231, or equivalent.

item.title: Stat 460: Mathematical statistics II (Spring 2018)
item.description: Syllabus Office hours MWF: 9-12; TH: 11-12 Resources Additional courses on R provided by Data Camp Base R R Studio ggplot2 cheat sheet R Markdown cheat sheet Notes Chapter 7: Sampling distributions | pdf | Rmd Chapter 8: Properties of estimators | pdf | Rmd Chapter 9: Methods of estimation | pdf | Rmd Chapter 10: Hypothesis testing | pdf | Rmd Chapcter 16: Bayesian methods | pdf | Rmd Chapter 15: Nonparametric methods | pdf | Rmd

item.title: Syllabus
item.description: STAT 460: Mathematical statistics II Spring 2018 Prerequisite: Stat 450 Course summary STAT 460 is a continuation of the mathematical statistics sequence. Stat 460 turns from properties of a single distribution (the focus of Stat 450), and turns to properties of estimation and foundational concepts of statistical inference. Specific topics include consistency, bias, and methods of finding estimators; confidence interval coverage; hypothesis test properties and optimum R will be of even greater use to us in this semester.

item.title: Play Day Task
item.description: This play day is modified from a similar assignment by Jerzy Wieczorek of CivilStat.com specifically this one. Consider data tablulated from the 2010 Digest of Education Statistics, tables 308 to 330.. The intent of this data is to answer: In what fields are more women entering college? How is each field’s gender balance changing? Is there a difference in gender balance comparing STEM to non-STEM fields? How has the gender balance in STEM fields changed relative to the balance in non-STEM fields over time?

item.title: Final project
item.description: Description For your final project, you are to find your own data source(s) and create a “visual story” visualizing insights from the data. Your visual story should consist of at least 1 but no more than 3 dashboards visualizing these data. This project is “tool agnostic”: you may create your visualizations using Tableau, or R, or any other visualization software. The only requirement is that whatever software you use produces a final dashboard product that is ready-to-publish on the Internet.

item.title: R Homework 3
item.description: Due Wednesday, 11/8 by 11:59pm. Prepare your submission with R Markdown. Submit fully-knitted Word doc or pdf to D2L by due date. You are encouraged to use this .Rmd file as your starting point for your submission. In Math-Stat, all of the pmfs/pdfs we have discussed are truly models. This means they are proposed mathematical frameworks for explaining behavior of actual data. We consier one proposed model for some actual data in this problem.

item.title: Play Day Task
item.description: Consider the following data on World Migration from the United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division, Trends in International Migrant Stock. Questions to be answered visually (no restrictions!): Which countries and regions have the most people leaving? Where do they go? Which countries and regions have the most people entering? Where do they come from?

item.title: Introduction to data visualization in R using ggplot2
item.description: Overview Basic grammar Hadleyâ€™s Grammar of Graphics is outlined in detail in this article. Here, he illustrates his principles using a small data set similar to the following: df <- data.frame(A = c(2,1,4,9), B = c(4,1,15,80), C = c(1,2,3,4), D = c('far','far','near','near')) head(df) ## A B C D ## 1 2 4 1 far ## 2 1 1 2 far ## 3 4 15 3 near ## 4 9 80 4 near To visualize any data set using the Grammar of Graphics, it helps to understand the 3 components of which any graph is comprised:

item.title: Midterm project
item.description: For this semester’s midterm project, we will be participating in the American Statistical Association’s Police Data Challenge. Read the information on the website for many more details. For the midterm project, all students should visualize the Seattle data set. Detailed version of the rules. Fill out declaration of intent form by Friday, October 6. Only one team member needs to submit the form. List me (Silas Bergen) as your sponsor.

item.title: Play Day Task
item.description: Consider the Major League Baseball Standings data. There are two worksheets in this Excel file: one with 2016 standings, and one with 2017 standings. The important variables in each are the team names ™; actual winning percentage (W-L%); and predicted winning percentage (pythWPct), which is each team’s predicted winning percentage based on the number of points (“runs”) scored by and against that team. Questions to be answered (no restrictions!): Which teams’ winning percentages most improved the most from 2016-2017?

item.title: R Homework 1
item.description: Due Friday, 9/8 by 11:59pm. Prepare your submission with R Markdown. Submit fully-knitted html, Word, or pdf to D2L by due date. You are encouraged to use this .Rmd file as your starting point for your submission. In class, we considered the case of rolling two dice, one red and one white. Let \(Y\equiv\) the minimum of the two rolls. Define the probability mass function (pmf) in tabular format. The table is started for you, below.

item.title: Syllabus (Fall 2017)
item.description: Data summarization and visualization (Fall 2017) Course overview The amount and extent of data in our world is growing extremely rapidly. As such there is an increasing need for analysts skilled in summarizing data. Visualizations are an immensely popular way of summarizing data, as they allow viewers to efficiently translate data into information. Modern visualizations are either static or interactive, with a growing trend towards the latter. In this course we will discuss how we perceive information visually, how to identify and avoid data visualization pitfalls, and how to create effective static and interactive visualizations.

item.title: Stat 365: Experimental design and analysis (Spring 2017)
item.description: Course materials Syllabus R cran R studio “Try R” tutorial (for R beginners) Intro to R Studio tutorial video “Ref-modify.docx” style document called in .Rmd files Handouts Handout 1: Review of modeling | House price data (.csv) | Video of completed Handout 1 | R Markdown (.Rmd) file Handout 2: Intro to experimental design Handout 3: Review of inference in the context of experimental design | .

item.title: Critique #1
item.description: Charles Joseph Minard’s famous visualization of Napoleon’s disastrous march on Russia in 1812 earned Ed Tufte’s glowing praise: “Probably the best statistical graphic ever drawn.” Read this excellent description and analysis by Joanne Cheng, then submit your answers to the following questions on D2L: What are the variables that are encoded in this visualization? For each, state whether it is categorical nominal; categorical ordinal; or quantitative. What elementary perceptual tasks are used to encode each variable?

item.title: Critique 2
item.description: As we move closer to designing more complex dashboards, this assignment has you read Chapters 3 (Thirteen Common Mistakes in Dashboard Designs), 7 (Designing Dashboards for Usability), and excerpts from Chapter 8 (sales dashboard examples) from Stephen Few’s 2006 book Information Dashboard Design. I have scanned the relevant chapters for you. After reading Chapter 3 and 7, look at the eight sample sales dashboards from Chapter 8. Prepare 3 bullet points critiquing each dashboard (so 24 bullet points total), using the ideas from Chapters 3 and 7, and submit these to D2L.

item.title: Example flex dash
item.description: Row Chart 1 plot(cars) Row Chart 2 plot(pressure) Chart 3 plot(airmiles)

item.title: IPUMS visualization in ggplot2
item.description: Code for tasks: library(dplyr);library(ggplot2) ipums <- read.csv('C:/Users/rt1875bv/Dropbox/DataViz/Data/IPUMS-Sex-EdAttain.csv') usa <- ipums %>% filter(Country=='United States') #head(usa) ggplot(data = usa) + geom_line(aes(x = Sex, y = Count, group = EdAttain, color=EdAttain), size = 2) + geom_point(aes(x = Sex, y = Count, shape = Sex),size=2) + facet_grid(.~Year) + scale_color_discrete(name='Highest education attained') + theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle=90)) + scale_y_continuous(name='Count (in millions)', labels = function(x) paste(x / 1000000,'M')) With percents instead of counts: usa2 <- usa%>%group_by(Year,Sex)%>%mutate(pct = 100*Count/sum(Count)) #head(usa2) ggplot(data = usa2) + geom_line(aes(x = Sex, y = pct, group = EdAttain, color=EdAttain), size = 2) + geom_point(aes(x = Sex, y = pct, shape = Sex,color=EdAttain),size=4) + facet_grid(.

item.title: IPUMS visualization in ggplot2
item.description: Recall the previous design task where we wanted to visualize changes in educational attainment over time, along with inequity by sex and how that might be changing. One possible visualization is shown below. Can you re-create this visualization? (Below is for the USA, but you can pick your country of interest.) library(dplyr);library(ggplot2) ipums <- read.csv('C:/Users/rt1875bv/Dropbox/DataViz/Data/IPUMS-Sex-EdAttain.csv') usa <- ipums %>% filter(Country=='United States') #head(usa) ggplot(data = usa) + geom_line(aes(x = Sex, y = Count, group = EdAttain, color=EdAttain), size = 2) + geom_point(aes(x = Sex, y = Count, shape = Sex),size=2) + facet_grid(.

item.title: R Homework 2
item.description: Due Wednesday, 9/20 by 11:59pm. Prepare your submission with R Markdown. Submit fully-knitted html, Word, or pdf to D2L by due date. You are encouraged to use this .Rmd file as your starting point for your submission. (Modified from Introduction to Scientific Programming and Simulation Using R by Owen Jones et al). A roulette wheel has 37 slots. 18 of these are colored red, 18 are black, and 1 slot (numbered 0) is colored green.
